title: 106_hr1733
content: The "Paul E. Tsongas Fellowship Act" aims to encourage individuals, especially those from underrepresented groups, to pursue careers in addressing global energy and environmental challenges. This Act authorizes doctoral fellowships. The Secretary of Energy is authorized to award Paul E. Tsongas Doctoral Fellowships for study and research in energy or environmental fields such as physics, mathematics, chemistry, biology, and social sciences. Fellowships are awarded for three academic years and can be used at any accredited institution. Number of Fellowships awarded annually under the Act shall be fully funded. Recipients are designated as "Paul E. Tsongas Fellows" or simply "Fellows." SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION OF FELLOWS. Eligibility for awards under this Act is limited to United States citizens. The Secretary, in consultation with the Director of the National Science Foundation, appoints a Paul E. Tsongas Fellowship Board consisting of 5 representatives from the academic science and engineering communities. The Board is responsible for establishing policies and criteria for awarding fellowships. The Paul E. Tsongas Fellowship Board consists of 5 representatives from the academic science and engineering communities. The Board establishes criteria for awarding fellowships, awards them, and submits a report to Congress every 3 years. Board members serve a 3-year term, with a maximum of 6 years. The Secretary calls the first meeting to elect a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Board members serve a 2-year term, with the Chairperson serving until 1 year after appointment. Vacancies are filled by the Board. A majority constitutes a quorum for meetings held at least once a year. Members receive compensation fixed by the Secretary. The Board members serve a 2-year term, with the Chairperson serving until 1 year after appointment. Vacancies are filled by the Board. A majority constitutes a quorum for meetings held at least once a year. Members receive compensation fixed by the Secretary. In designing selection criteria and awarding fellowships, the Board shall consider the need to prepare a larger number of women and individuals from minority groups, especially from among those traditionally underrepresented in professional and academic fields. No preference or disparate treatment is required for underrepresented groups. The Board considers expanding access for women and minority groups to underrepresented careers. SEC. 5. PAYMENTS, STIPENDS, TUITION, AND EDUCATION AWARDS. The Secretary will provide stipends of $15,000, $16,500, and $18,000 over three years, cover tuition, fees, and health insurance, and allocate a $5,000 annual allowance for administrative and travel expenses to individuals awarded fellowships under this Act. The Act provides round-trip travel expenses for Fellows participating in the internship required by the Act. Each Fellow must complete a 3-month internship related to their dissertation topic at a national laboratory, industrial laboratory, or approved institution. Fellowship conditions apply. No student receiving support under this Act must maintain satisfactory progress in their field of study or research, and not engage in gainful employment except for part-time teaching, research, or similar activities. The Secretary can require reports from fellowship recipients as needed. (c) Failure To Earn Degree.--A recipient of a fellowship under this Act found by the Secretary to have failed in or abandoned the course of study may be required to repay a pro rata amount of the fellowship assistance received, plus interest and collection fees, as determined by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and as needed for future years. The General Educational Provisions Act's Section 421 regarding fund availability applies to this Act. Definitions include the Secretary of Energy as "Secretary" and the institution where a Paul E. Tsongas Fellow pursues doctoral studies as "host institution."
